item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 10:25:17+00:00 (#7787)
item.description: VEH?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 10:24:43+00:00 (#7786)
item.description: if we are talking about the driver, is there a VEH?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 10:22:28+00:00 (#7785)
item.description: But, there should be articles online that they already analyzed SEH. I think this way of analyzing SEH from IDT entries is so fundamental and time consuming. There should be better and easier ways for analyzing SEH. ü§î

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 10:19:54+00:00 (#7784)
item.description: Nope. It's possible in HyperDbg. But it's not possible in WinDbg.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 10:19:25+00:00 (#7783)
item.description:
This is also a unique aspect of HyperDbg. You cannot trace instructions in ISRs (IDT functions) in WinDbg but you can do it in HyperDbg. üôÇ
Make sure to use the instrumentation step-in instead of regular step-in.
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/debugging-commands/i

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 09:53:55+00:00 (#7782)
item.description: if I put a breakpoint through hyperdbg will I also get a hang?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 09:50:43+00:00 (#7781)
item.description: I tried to put a breakpoint in windbg on the handler function in the idt table, but the system was hanging

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 09:18:27+00:00 (#7780)
item.description: You need to check how Microsoft implemented the SEH in newer Windows versions.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 09:17:39+00:00 (#7779)
item.description: I'm not sure how SEH works these days. A few years ago, it was like putting the address of SEH Handler in the stack but I'm not sure if it still works the same way.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 09:15:56+00:00 (#7778)
item.description: Yes, that's right.... what should the script look like for !exception

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 09:12:27+00:00 (#7777)
item.description: So, you need to find the handler using a simple script using the same !exception command.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 09:10:54+00:00 (#7776)
item.description: we don't need to ignore the exception, but we need to track where the handler of this exception is located (the code in catch).

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-09-01 08:51:36+00:00 (#7775)
item.description:
Yes. You can use the !exception command combined with the event short circuiting mechanism.
By default, if an exception/fault/interrupt happens in the system, HyperDbg re-injects it to the guest.
You can decide whether you want it to be injected to the guest and be handled by Windows or drop it and ignore it by short circuiting it.
Please check: https://docs.hyperdbg.org/tips-and-tricks/misc/event-short-circuiting

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-09-01 07:09:26+00:00 (#7774)
@HughEverett on 2024-08-31 15:17:29+00:00 (#7772)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 15:16:42+00:00 (#7771)
item.description:
You can use event calling stages for it. Check the first example of the !monitor command here:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/tips-and-tricks/misc/event-calling-stage

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 05:04:24+00:00 (#7763)
item.description:
It's not just kernel, HyperDbg support both user mode and kernel mode in the Debugger Mode:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/using-hyperdbg/prerequisites/operation-modes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 05:02:38+00:00 (#7762)
item.description: Some solution that came to my mind about distinguishing between read/write is checking it with the target instruction (current @rip). Basically, you need read the @rip using memcpy in the script engine and make a basic instruction disassembler for MOV commands.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 05:00:37+00:00 (#7761)
item.description: Right now, the !monitor command cannot distinguish between read/write/execute but that's a really good feature to be added to it. I'll add it to the todo list.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 04:55:01+00:00 (#7758)
item.description: If you're using the script engine the '$context' shows the vector number.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 04:53:15+00:00 (#7757)
item.description: For INT3 which is #BP, you can use test breakpoint off test breakpoint on

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-31 04:52:36+00:00 (#7756)
item.description: INT1 is #DB which you can disable or enable it by using: test trap off test trap on

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-08-30 00:08:16+00:00 (#7748)
item.description:
[discord] <.wxg> [reply]: I use separate write and read scripts because I don't know how to distinguish between read and write operations in DS. For MMIO, it would be very unreasonable to use a 4K page as the basic unit for EPTHOOK2. Of course, it would be best if DS could distinguish between write and read operations.
In my scenario, most of what I want to achieve is similar to the mmiotrace provided by the Linux kernel.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-08-29 15:40:59+00:00 (#7747)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-29 12:58:02+00:00 (#7745)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PX38N5F3SL8&list=PLUFkSN0XLZ-kF1f143wlw8ujlH2A45nZY&index=34

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-29 12:56:44+00:00 (#7744)
item.description: It's probably because the way that we check for the validity of the address is not working for MMIOs. Could you please open an issue on GitHub? So, it will be fixed.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-29 12:55:23+00:00 (#7743)
item.description:
You can have as many !monitor hooks as you want but only one hook within a 4 KB boundary of a page. For example, if you put a hook 0x12345678, you cannot put any more hooks on 0x12345000 to 0x12345fff (within a page boundary). For using multiple hooks you can hook an entire range and then manage the occurrence of each hook using its script (by checking with the $context pseudo-register).
> How can I unhook an address that is being monitored by !monitor?
The !monitor hook as well as almost all of the features of HyperDbg are exported as events. Events can be disabled/removed using the 'events' command.
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/debugging-commands/events

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-29 12:49:43+00:00 (#7742)
item.description: What do you mean by 'debugging interrupts'? ü§î

item.description: [discord] <.wxg> [reply]: When using the !monitor command, I found that it incorrectly identifies the correct MMIO address as invalid. https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1278419624672628756/image.png?ex=66d0bc8e&is=66cf6b0e&hm=2fb65cf2d3cfd3139427d8e3d292b2c2bd79aabb7ab9e0c990c2656bf3b91f0a&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-08-28 17:22:05+00:00 (#7738)
item.description:
[discord] <.wxg> Dear HyperDbg Team,
I have two questions regarding the !monitor command:
How can I set two different Debug Scripts (DS) with !monitor, one for write and one for read operations? When I try to use !monitor r and !monitor w to set two different scripts, I receive an error indicating that the same address cannot be set twice.
How can I unhook an address that is being monitored by !monitor?
Thank you for your assistance.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-08-28 09:55:23+00:00 (#7737)
item.description: test trap off - disables the trap flag. is there any way to disable the processing of all debugging interrupts?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-27 11:27:39+00:00 (#7734)
item.description: Yes. The parameters in the HyperDbg's VMX event handler are correctly configured.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-27 11:26:41+00:00 (#7733)
item.description: Ah, sorry for the very late response. That's really cool. You can start with Hypervisor From Scratch to know about the starting points and internals: https://rayanfam.com/tutorials/

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-08-26 13:19:25+00:00 (#7732)
item.description: [discord] <kanrab> Hey. I‚Äôd like to contribute but I‚Äôm a bit of a newbie when it comes to contributing to large projects. I hope you don‚Äôt mind some newbie questions and I‚Äôm happy to be here :)!

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-08-25 17:23:56+00:00 (#7731)
item.description: so the parameters in the project are set correctly and nothing needs to be changed? analog operation in hyperdbg "trap flag off"

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-25 17:05:22+00:00 (#7730)
item.description: It will be injected by processor to the target guest. And it's handled by the operating system.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-08-25 05:59:55+00:00 (#7729)
item.description: Thanks for the answer! This is your example of hypervisor from scratch 8. Does it send interrupt handling to the operating system by default?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-25 04:45:52+00:00 (#7728)
item.description:
It will be injected immediately after the processor resumes in the vmx non-root mode.
Other than that, the ability to inject is also exported in the script engine as functions with/without error code, you can use these function:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/scripting-language/functions/events/event_inject
and
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/scripting-language/functions/events/event_inject_error_code

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-25 04:43:03+00:00 (#7727)
item.description: There are a couple of functions for injecting different interrupts/exceptions/faults in this file, you can use it: https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/blob/master/hyperdbg/hyperhv/code/vmm/vmx/Events.c

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-08-24 20:04:34+00:00 (#7726)
item.description: can you pls explain in short how that counter works? does it just gets increased when event is triggered or there is some more complex logic underneath ?
